prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TDs with small holes
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Primary science goal of this proposal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main target lines are 12CO and 13CO 2-1. For 12CO, we expect high enough S/N on the line to see the disk kinematics, hence a high spectral resolution is chosen. For all other lines, we will bin in velocity space to at least 1 km/s to obtain higher S/N on the lines. By choosing to observe both 12CO and 13CO, both lines are at the end of the correlator bandwidth increasing the noise by about 10%, but this does not affect our science goals. The correlator setting includes C18O 2-1, DCN 3-2, C3H2 and H2CO. The latter two molecules are characteristic of warm chemistry exposed to UV, as expected in the inner 10s of au of disks, whereas DCN is a colder gas tracer and C18O provides a further check on optical depth. These species are not central to the science case and are not expected to be detected at the highest angular resolution but could show up with a beam tapered to somewhat lower angular resolution. Spectral averaging has been set to limit the data rate to below 12 Mb/sec.

The high angular resolution of 0.05" is driven by the need to resolve the small cavities in these transitional disks, down to 8 (+- a few) AU. Disk sizes are typically a few arcsec in diameter, but our focus is on the inner 30 AU (radius) of the disk. To constrain the outer disk, relevant for goal d, a separate science goal for C36-4 is added.

Assuming typical Band 6 weather conditions and phase noise, a 45 min on source ALMA observation reaches 38 microJy/beam for the continuum in one 1875 MHz baseband, whereas the rms noise in each 1 km/s channel is 2.2-2.5 mJy/beam (17.5 K). The model images presented in Figure 3 reach a maximum of 4 mJy/beam for the continuum and 55 mJy/beam km/s for 12CO 2-1 inside the hole in the delta_gas = 1 model, down to 25 mJy/beam km/s for the delta_gas= 10-3 model. Thus, S/N = 105 is reached at the peak continuum, and S/N of at least 25 and 10 for the 12CO line down to delta_gas= 10-3. Although the model uncertainties are at the level of a factor of a few, it is clear that this sensitivity will allow deep searches for gas inside the hole down to delta_gas= 10-3. For delta_gas close to 1, the more optically thin 13CO line may be just detectable with velocity binning. With this sensitivity, the mm-sized dust can be detected inside the hole down to delta_dust= 10-5 with a S/N of 3 (0.1 mJy/bm). The integration time of 45 min per source is dictated by the sensitivity requirement to obtain a large dynamic range on the inferred gas mass down to delta_gas = 10-3.
The peak line flux listed for the dynamic range calculation is around 20 mJy/beam, dominated by the outer disk. With the C36-7 configuration, a single pointing in Band 6 will filter out the outer disk emission beyond the 50 AU radius (0.65"). Since our focus is on the inner 30 AU radius of the disk, where the maximum sensitivity is needed, this is fine to reach our main science goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: TDs large scale
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal is added to obtain the outer disk (>50 AU) gas and dust surface density distribution (filtered out in the high angular resolution data) with configuration C36-4, which will increase the accuracy of goal d described in the proposal. Setup is otherwise the same as for our primary science goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main target line for this science goal is 13CO 2-1. The 12CO line is optically thick but high spectral resolution can be used to probe the disk kinematics. Based on our models, we expect to detect the 13CO 2-1 line with enough S/N for kinematics. By choosing to observe both 12CO and 13CO simultaneously, both lines are at the end of the correlator bandwidth increasing the noise by about 10%, but this does not affect our science goals. For all other lines we will bin to at least 1 km/s to obtain higher S/N. The correlator setting includes C18O 2-1, DCN 3-2, C3H2 and H2CO, providing serendipitous related science. The latter two molecules are characteristic of warm chemistry exposed to UV, as expected in the inner 10s of au of disks, whereas DCN is a colder gas tracer and C18O provides a further check on optical depth (although unlikely to be detected in these low-mass disks). Velocity averaging is used to bring the data rate down below 12 Mb/s.

The angular resolution of 0.3" is driven by the need to constrain the outer disk surface density profile on scales of tens of au. Disk sizes are typically a few arcsec in diameter which sets the largest angular scale.

Assuming typical Band 6 weather conditions and phase noise, a 11 min on source ALMA observation reaches 0.1 mJy/beam for the continuum in one 1875 MHz baseband, whereas the rms noise in each 1 km/s channel is 4.0 mJy/beam (1 K) for a 0.35" beam. For this science goal the focus is on the (optically thin) 13CO 2-1 to constrain the gas surface density distribution in the outer disk. Model images such as presented in Figure 3 but at 0.3" resolution show that the continuum is typically a few mJy/beam whereas the lines are typically 50 mJy/beam km/s for 13CO 2-1. Thus, S/N = 12 is reached for 13CO. The integration time of 11 min per source is dictated by the sensitivity requirement to obtain a detection of the optically thin 13CO 2-1 (Miotello et al. 2014).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Transitional disks with dust cavities form the best laboratory for studying disk evolution and planet formation 'in action'. Different explanations for their structure have been put forward, ranging from embedded young planets clearing their surroundings to photoevaporation and grain growth. So far, all ALMA observations have targeted disks with large cavities (>15 AU) that could be resolved in Cycles 0-2 and for which the presence of a massive companion is a likely explanation. In contrast, models predict that small hole sizes may be due to photoevaporation. Here we use the enhanced long baseline capabilities of ALMA Cycle 3 to resolve the small cavities (<15 AU) for the first time. Observations of both the gas and dust, combined with our state-of-the-art models, will be able to determine the physical processes at work and whether there are indeed (at least) two classes of transitional disks.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
